Hi Neeraj,

I ran into a similar case a month ago, and found that the JVM was crashing on a
"return x;" statement. However, JVM crashes are *always* a JVM bug. There's
nothing you can do in Java to crash a VM, even on purpose. (unless of course you
know a weakness in a particular VM)

Please contact the vendor of the JVM you're using and report the bug. If you get
any information back about the corefile or the problem, there may be something
we can workaround until the JVM is fixed, but until then there is not much we
can do.

Hi Tim,

We have had no change in environment, and this started happenening this week.
Any other ideas?  We can log the error with the IBM JDK team - but still
wondering what happened.

- Chuck

Hi Neeraj,

That error appears to be caused because you have different levels of the
jst.server.core and jst.server.tomcat.core plugins. The build would have
reported an error if the files were wrong there, so my guess is that you are
using a build as a target and pulling other plugins out of CVS. Is this the
case? If so, just grab a new build as a target, or pull in all the wst.server.*
and jst.server.* plugins from CVS so that that they are all at the same level,
or use the releng tools to pull a consistent level.

Thanks  Tim, verified with  the  04/22  driver and  with the  updated code 
doesn't happen  anymore.
